nodes.text: A lexicon-based system (SO-CAL) that uses hand-ranked multi-part-of-speech dictionaries plus linguistic handling of intensification, negation, irrealis, and text-level weighting can robustly and portably extract sentiment polarity and strength across domains
SO-CAL uses hand-ranked dictionaries for adjectives, nouns, verbs, and adverbs with scores on a -5 to +5 prior-polarity scale and some multi-word entries

SO-CAL models intensification via a percentage-based modifier lexicon (amplifiers positive, downtoners negative) applied multiplicatively and recursively, and treats adjectival intensifiers separately when modifying nouns

SO-CAL implements negation primarily as a polarity shift (subtract fixed amount toward opposite polarity) with conservative backward search for scope, and irrealis blocking to ignore SO in non-factual contexts

SO-CAL applies text-level features: increased weight for negative expressions, repetition downweighting (nth occurrence has 1/n weight), configurable positional/XML weighting, and supports multiple cut-offs for granular classing

Dictionaries were created manually from diverse sources (Epinions, movie Polarity Dataset, General Inquirer), reviewed by multiple researchers, and multi-word expressions and part-of-speech distinctions were included to reduce noise

SO-CAL was evaluated on multiple corpora (Epinions 400, additional Epinions 400, Polarity movie reviews ~1900, Camera reviews 2400) and on shorter texts (MPQA sentences, MySpace comments, news/blog sentences, Affective headlines)
Linguistic features (intensification, negation shift, irrealis, repetition weighting, negative weighting) each contribute to improved polarity classification when combined with a fine-grained lexicon
Polarity shift negation (shifting toward opposite polarity) better models human intuition and pragmatic effects of negation than a simple polarity flip in many cases
Manual dictionaries with controlled inclusion (exclude ambiguous/neutral words, limit noisy rare words) produce better cross-domain performance than larger automatically-generated lexicons

Mechanical Turk validation: human judgments (single-word polarity and pairwise strength comparisons) largely correspond to the manual SO rankings, with higher agreement at stronger SO magnitudes and more disagreement near neutral/weak values

SO-CAL full system achieves substantially higher accuracy than basic word-counting or many automatic dictionaries across test corpora (overall ~78.7% with full features versus lower for alternatives), and performance is stable across seen and unseen review domains

On shorter or non-review texts SO-CAL classifies only texts that contain SO-carrying words; excluding SO-empty texts yields accuracies comparable to review-level performance (around 75â€“83%), while back-off for empty texts still outperforms majority baselines

Mechanical Turk comparisons of negated positives versus negatives show mixed human judgments; overall MT data slightly favors the shift model over switch, but negation remains complex and neither model fully captures all cases

Compared to other lexicons (Google PMI automatic, SentiWordNet, Maryland, General Inquirer, Subjectivity lexicon), SO-CAL with hand-ranked multi-pos dictionaries plus linguistic features yields the best and most consistent cross-domain polarity results

Limitations and future work: negation modeling remains imperfect, sentence-level and short-text sparsity (SO-empty cases) limit direct application, and further gains expected by integrating discourse-level and topic/comment paragraph weighting, cross-linguistic dictionary building, and improved word-sense handling
